fields.description:
As per the summary, I cannot see anything in the activity stream.

1) When I browse to FishEye (not yet logged-in), I don't see anything in the activity stream and I am an administrator of FishEye. See screenshot 1.jpg.

2) After I log in, I still cannot see anything in the activity stream despite clearly having commit activity. See screenshot 2.jpg.

3) However, if I log out and clear my browser cache, I can see items in the activity stream as expected. Once I try to log in, I don't see anything again and even after logging out, the activity stream remains empty. I can only see items in it when I clear my browser cache.

None of the above happens for the other accounts, only mine. As a result, I suspect there is something wrong with my profile, but I don't know how to fix it.
fields.summary: Activity stream in FishEye is blank.

fields.description:
There is an option to upload profile picture (avatar) via Profile Settings > Profile & Email when Gravatar is enabled. However, uploading an image does not change the profile picture. This is confusing/misleading the users. 

When Gravatar is enabled, FishEye/Crucible should not have the option to upload profile picture and mention that Gravatar is being used.

fields.description:
In Oracle, you can't use "distinct" in queries on tables with CLOB types. Hibernate isn't aware of this, a known bug: https://hibernate.atlassian.net/browse/HHH-3606

This impacts the new permissions checking.

Exception:
{noformat}
013-06-25 14:51:57,701 WARN [qtp572487432-222 ] org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter JDBCExceptionReporter-logExceptions - SQL Error: 932, SQLState: 42000
2013-06-25 14:51:57,702 ERROR [qtp572487432-222 ] org.hibernate.util.JDBCExceptionReporter JDBCExceptionReporter-logExceptions - ORA-00932: inconsistent datatypes: expected - got CLOB

2013-06-25 14:51:57,703 ERROR [qtp572487432-222 ] com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.error.jersey.ThrowableExceptionMapper ThrowableExceptionMapper-toResponse - Uncaught exception thrown by REST service
org.hibernate.exception.SQLGrammarException: could not execute query
at org.hibernate.exception.SQLStateConverter.convert(SQLStateConverter.java:92)
{noformat}
fields.summary: Can't use distinct in queries on tables with CLOB types in Oracle

fields.description:
It would be useful if the changesets listed in the source tab of a Jira issue could show any changesets where the branch name contains the ticket key.

There are many people using a source control workflow of making a new branch for each new feature or bug fix. Using the ticket key in the feature branch name would allow marking all changesets in that branch as part of that ticket's work.
fields.summary: Look for issue key in branch name

fields.description:
Hi,

We tried to import users from JIRA to FishEye using JIRA/Crowd Authentication under Administration->Security Settings->Authentication->JIRA/Crowd Authentication with the following settings:

- Authenticate against: a JIRA instance 
- Auto-add: Create a FishEye user on successful login
- Periodically synchronise users with Crowd - yes, 1 hour
- When Synchronisation Happens: Copy new users and changes to existing users (local editing of email address and display name is disabled).
- Groups To Synchronise: jira-administrators

This work, however, this step also sync all groups. see attached video

Is there a way to set to sync only for the list of groups defined?

fields.description:
We have discovered a vulnerability in WebWork 2, which is a part of the Struts web framework. 

In specific circumstances, attackers can use this vulnerability to execute Java code of their choice on systems that use these frameworks. 

In case of Fisheye, the attacker needs to be able to access Fisheye Web interface. A valid user account is not is required to exploit this vulnerability.

Customers should be advised that this effects all previously released versions of Fisheye, except Fisheye OnDemand, Fisheye 2.10.6 (or later) and Fisheye 3.0.2 (or later).

For more information on this issue, please see the security advisory [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/FishEye+and+Crucible+Security+Advisory+2013-07-16].
fields.summary: Webwork 2 code injection vulnerability

fields.description:
When an EyeQL request is taking too long or it does not succeed, FishEye/Crucible should have a mechanism to timeout the request within a defined amount of time.

In short:
# Check for EyeQL validity and terminate a query if not valid.
# Add a timeout to the query - configurable via FishEye/Crucible UI; if it exceeds this limit.

Example query (on a large repository):
{noformat}
/?ql=select revisions where date in [2013-04-16%2C 2013-04-17]%0D%0Aand (not in any review)%0D%0Aand path like somepath%2F*%0D%0Aorder by date desc%0D%0Areturn csid%2C comment%2C date%2C author%2C path&refresh=y
{noformat}
fields.summary: Improve Validity and Timeout Handling for EyeQL

fields.description:
As per the [JIRA Fisheye integration guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/JIRA+Integration+in+FishEye], the following steps are required for a successful linking between JIRA issue keys and Fisheye changesets:

{noformat}
- JIRA requires FishEye to manually refresh repository cache when repository changes are made — When a repository is removed, or when there has been any change in FishEye repositories, JIRA does not update the FishEye repository list cache automatically. You must manually refresh the repository list cache. This is done in JIRA: 'Administration' > 'FishEye Configuration' > 'Refresh Cache' link (next to 'Repository List Cache')
- FishEye doesn't check for invalid JIRA issue keys – FishEye doesn't check for invalid issue keys, such as UTF-8. An error will result if FishEye tries to connect to an issue that doesn't exist.
- FishEye doesn't recognise custom JIRA issue key formats – FishEye assumes that JIRA issue keys are of the default format for JIRA 5.0 and later: that is, up to 10 letters, followed by a hyphen and the issue number (i.e. [a-zA-Z]{10}-[0-9]+), for example FishEye-123. 
{noformat}

But it also seems like custom JIRA issue key patterns are supported by Fisheye afterall, as the commits with these issue keys are being linked successfully to JIRA issue and displayed under the "Source" tab in JIRA.
There is however an issue with how these JIRA issue keys are linked/rendered in Fisheye in the activity stream:
- A JIRA project key such as "ABC_DE", for example: ABC_DE-1 is being rendered as a linked URL in Fisheye activity stream and when clicked takes the user to the related JIRA issue.
- A JIRA project key such as "ABCD100_EF", for example: ABCD100_EF-1 is not being rendered as a linked URL in Fisheye activity stream and hence cannot take the user to the linked JIRA issue. 
- The linked commit for both keys however is successfully listed under the "Source" tab in JIRA.

JIRA [has announced|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/End+of+Support+Announcements+for+JIRA#EndofSupportAnnouncementsforJIRA-Endofsupportforprojectkeyformatconfiguration%2822November2012%29] end of support for custom keys other than those with digit, underscore and numbers in the keys and the above examples belong to the "supported" format. If Fisheye does not supported custom JIRA issue keys, then none of the above two should be linked in JIRA or Fisheye. If they are however supported, then we need to revise the above document and have a consistent behaviour for all custom JIRA issue keys.
fields.summary: Some custom JIRA issue key patterns not linked in activity stream

fields.description:
Steps for replication:
{noformat}
1. Modify a file
2. git commit
3. git revert the above commit after a minute
5. git cherry-pick -e the above commit after a minute
6. git log
shows the cherry-pick timestamp as the first/most recent activity
7. View in FishEye; the order is
intermediate - git revert
newest - git cherry-pick
oldest - original commit
{noformat}
fields.summary: Git changelog out of order with git revert

fields.description: The Code Metrics Report does not currently allow for any filters.  Requesting at least a date range filter to view Top Committers by date range.
fields.summary: Code Metrics Report - add date range

fields.description:
When given two authors in history, User1 and User2, mapped to a single FishEye User3, on the Code Metrics Report, User1 and User2 are listed instead of User3 as anticipated.

This is an issue when importing from existing repositories with lots of history and usernames changed in FishEye.  The metrics reports are off.
fields.summary: Code Metrics Report: "Top Committers - By LOC" does not group authors by mapping

fields.description: Need REST API to associate more than 50 groups with different repositories
fields.summary: Add a REST endpoint for permission to associate a group with a repository

fields.description:
We have defined a process to [synchronize with large user groups|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Synchronising+With+Large+User+Repositori] but there is no way to update user data (e.g. e-mail) en-mass and regularly.

Introduce a new option under "When Synchronisation Happens":

- *Copy changes to existing users (local editing of email address and display name is disabled).*
- Copy new users and changes to existing users (local editing of email address and display name is disabled). 
- Copy only new users (local editing of email address and display name is enabled).
fields.summary: Create ability to synchronize changes to existing users only

fields.description: FishEye worked a few days, then began to write the error for all repositories
fields.summary: FishEye cannot access to git repositories after updating to version 3.0

fields.description:
A major new release of Subversion, 1.8, was released June 18, 2013.  FishEye should be upgraded to support 1.8 repositories
.
http://subversion.apache.org/docs/release-notes/1.8.html
fields.summary: Subversion 1.8 Support

fields.description: It's a good idea the possibility to restrict API access to a certain user group instead of just grant access to authenticated users.
fields.summary: Improve remote API access rules adding the possibility to restrict it to a certain user group.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Login to FishEye/Crucible and select an SVN repository.
# Go to Reports/Charts.
# [Select the "Area" chart type, the page reloads and the chart type jumps back to "Line"|^screenshot1.png].
# [Set the "Break down by: Author", and push "Apply"|^screenshot2.png].
# The settings are reset and nothing happens.

This was working in FishEye/Crucible 2.10
fields.summary: Break Down By Author Report/Chart Broken

fields.description: When searching for some key word into GIT repository and FishEye found some files with searched keyword. Then if I open that file, keywords are not hilighted into the file and it is hard to orientate where FishEye found those words. If I use browser's search function then for larger files Crucible is not loaded whole content and browser's search does not find anything.
fields.summary: Highlighting of found words in FishEye after search

fields.summary: "All repo" user prefs cause problems on Oracle

fields.description:
The graph view is ordered by commit date, but displays the author date. The commit date, i.e. when the revision landed in the branch, is useful to know as cherry-picked commits often have different author and commit information. 

It would be great if the commit info was shown in the graph view as well, maybe only when it differs from the author info?

Additionally it would be nice to have this information available in the Commit Details view.
fields.summary: Show git commit info in addition to author info

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Create a user with Polish character 'Żywioł'
# Get the result of the REST API '/rest-service/users-v1'
{noformat}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<users>
	<userData>
		<avatarUrl>http://localhost:8060/avatar/test?s=48</avatarUrl>
		<displayName>?ywio?</displayName>
		<userName>test</userName>
	</userData>
</users>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Rest call does not return a valid Polish character

fields.description:
I searched answers and the FE project first, and didn't see this asked. We have Fisheye indexing about 90 of our git repos and while I've found some success with hyphen deliminated pathing in Fisheye, the usability of Fisheye is rapidly breaking down as the volume of repositories indexed by Fisheye goes up and up. 

We have two different Git servers; gitosis (which allows unlimited nesting) and Stash (which only allows one level of nesting). 
For Gitosis, this is common:
http://gitosis.host.name/git/toplevel/nextlevel/bottomlevel/finally.git
Which in Fisheye I setup as:
Toplevel-Nextlevel-Bottomlevel-Finally
Which helps users find what they are looking for, given they are used to the many-level nesting. 
For Stash repos, I use the project key, hyphen, repo name.
Assuming the project in Stash is called "Project" and the key is "PROJ", so something like:
http://stash.host.name/scm/proj/project.git
In Fisheye I setup as:
PROJ-Project
I've gotten positive feedback from users on this method, as it helps people find what they are looking for quickly and easily, relatively. But as the number of repositories indexed by Fisheye increases, the huge pull-down list is not friendly to the average user, and having to flip-flip-flip page after page to look for your repo in other areas of the UI is turning into a negative user experience. So three requests, biggest to smallest:
1) Given how Jira & Stash have projects and Confluence has Spaces, can Fisheye repos be organized at least by a simple single-level folder structure?
2) Can a user set (or an admin set globally, I don't care) how many repos are shown on each page? 
3) Can an admin sort/filter on if a repository is erroring? Right now, I go to Adminstration, and watch the "Location" column. If there's an error (say, a remote git server went down, or something is taking so long the timeout is being reached before the git operation returns) it shows up in a big red box, but I have to flip through each page of repos looking for "big red boxes" do to a health check on Fisheye. 
4) Can there be admin email notifications on Fisheye errors? See #3 - it would be nice if Fisheye emailed me when a repo disappeared/was unreachable, not when a user opens up a Jira issue asking why none of the commits are being processed or showing up in Jira.
fields.summary: Repo Organization

fields.description: I searched answers and the FE project first, and didn't see this asked. We have Fisheye indexing about 90 of our git repos and while we have near-perfect committer naming standards, there's at least a few users that need author mapping to their login name. Unfortunately, it's on a per-repo basis. Can you add global author mapping as an option? Today we have 90 repos, but I expect us to top out at about 300 repos, and telling users they have to make 300 entries to cover everything is more an onerous, it's impossible.
fields.summary: Global User Mapping
Allow renaming FishEye&Crucible users

fields.description:
When creating an Application Link to another instance, Fisheye will populate the Application Navigator automatically using the Application URL instead of the expected Display URL.

This creates a problem when the App URL is an internal reference to a system, such as http://localhost:port. Fisheye may be able to contact the application with that URL, but the user cannot, and will most likely see a site unreachable message.

Workaround:

1) Hide the existing (automatically generated) App Nav entry using the Hide checkbox.
2) Create a new app link manually using the display URL.
fields.summary: Application Navigator uses Application URL instead of Display URL from Application Link

Hi there,

One customer gave a great idea for a new feature:
It was going to be awesome if we have a way to upload different revisions via patches and have the ability to go through the files revisions to see their evolution, because today this information can be checked only looking the files one by one.

Thanks.

fields.description: For example, in Python, indentation IS significant but are ignored with the "Ignore Insignificant Whitespace" setting enabled.
fields.summary: Hide insignificant whitespace setting is not language aware.

fields.description:
If you have a busy ticket, the "Source" tab may not load all the related changesets. At the bottom, there is a link to "Show more related changesets". Clicking this simply lists out the changesets: "Show more related changesets : PY:13985 , PY:13986 , PY:13987 , PY:13988 , PY:14002 , PY:14003 , PY:14004 , PY:14008 , PY:14011 , PY:14012 , PY:14013"

Instead, this should load the same kind of content as the changesets which are already displayed: The commit message, the changed files, etc.
fields.summary: Clicking "Show more related changesets" should load content like already-displayed changesets
Improve Smart Commit failure message for when using OAuth

fields.description:
Nowadays, when FishEye indexes a revision whose commit message contains a Smart Commit, if for some reason the Smart Commit could not be executed (e.g., problems commenting/transitioning a JIRA issue), it is lost forever. It won't be executed again even if the repository is re-indexed from scratch.

After fixing what blocked the Smart Commit from working, customers need to change anything in the source code and commit again.

It would be great to have a queue for non-executed Smart Commits. They will sit there until the problem is solved (so they're not lost forever) or until the customer accesses this queue and cancel them.
fields.summary: Add a queue for non-executed Smart Commits

fields.description: When a repo is configured to allow all logged in users and a custom authenticator is configured, the custom authenticator is still invoked and required to determine access to the repo explicity.
fields.summary: Custom Authenticator invoked even when all logged in users is selected

fields.description:
Nowadays these REST API calls return only the default repository:
* [/rest-service/projects-v1|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#d2e274]
* [/rest-service/projects-v1/<cru_proj_key>|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#d2e296]

Response example:
{code:xml}
<projectData expand="allowedReviewers">
      <allowedReviewers size="1"/>
      <allowReviewersToJoin>false</allowReviewersToJoin>
      <defaultObjectives/>
      <defaultRepositoryName>SVN</defaultRepositoryName>
      <defaultReviewers/>
      <id>2</id>
      <key>TST</key>
      <moderatorEnabled>false</moderatorEnabled>
      <name>Test</name>
      <permissionSchemeId>2</permissionSchemeId>
</projectData>
{code}

However, I have more than one repository associated with this Crucible project:
!RepoList.png!

If I want to retrieve them through one of the REST API calls above, only the default repository is retrieved.
fields.summary: REST API calls should retrieve all the repositories associated with a Crucible project

fields.description:
When viewing a repository in FishEye, and you drag the lefthand-side navigation bar to increase its size a certain width (or maximize the width), you can no longer expand folders inside the navigation bar to view its contents. 

To illustrate this, I have recorded a video: http://screencast.com/t/jPnK8qf4Ho
fields.summary: Cannot expand folders in navigation bar when navigation bar is resized to a certain width

fields.description:
Before I break my Fisheye installation by upgrading Mercurial (again), are you testing the latest Mercurial release as a matter of course?

For future reference, Mercurial releases a new major release every three months, per:

  http://mercurial.selenic.com/wiki/TimeBasedReleasePlan

It would be helpful if Atlassian performed these compatibility tests as a matter of course, rather than relying on customers to prod you to keep up. ;-)

Thanks

fields.description:
I have connected my AD in Crowd.
I can view all users and groups in Crowd.
I have set up an application called 'fisheye' in Crowd. I have added my AD and set 'allow all' to NO.
I then added a single group to the allowed groups.
As I understand, FishEye should only have users from this single group available to it.

However..

In FE I have added Crowd Authentication
In the next step I added my group from the list
When I go to 'Groups' in FE, I can still see all the groups in the AD.
I can add users to fisheye from these groups

Even though these users are added, they are not permitted to log in, this situation is confusing. Why are all users and groups visible in FE if user management has been configured to filter groups and users? Is it possible to only have the filtered list of users and groups visible?
fields.summary: List of users available to FishEye is not filtered as per Crowd setup

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce:
# Create an new repository with the command 'svnadmin reponame'
# Make sure that the file 'rep-cache.db' does not exist
# Add the repository into FishEye
Reindex will fail with the following error:
{noformat}
2013-05-02 09:18:57,038 INFO  [InitialPinger2 reponame] fisheye BaseRepositoryScanner-ping - processing dsagile-hmi
2013-05-02 09:18:57,038 DEBUG [InitialPinger2 reponame] fisheye SvnRepositoryTester-checkRepoSettings - Checking repository:  reponame:file:///path/to/repo/svn/reponame/
2013-05-02 09:18:57,038 DEBUG [SvnExecution1129 reponame] fisheye SvnTask-run - Executing info -r HEAD file:///path/to/repo/svn/reponame/@HEAD
2013-05-02 09:18:57,073 INFO  [SvnExecution1129 reponame] svnkit-fsfs DefaultSVNDebugLogger-log - FSFS: CANTOPEN
org.tmatesoft.sqljet.core.SqlJetException: CANTOPEN: error code is CANTOPEN
        at org.tmatesoft.sqljet.core.internal.fs.SqlJetFileSystem.open(SqlJetFileSystem.java:158)
        at org.tmatesoft.sqljet.core.internal.fs.SqlJetFileSystem.open(SqlJetFileSystem.java:185)
        at org.tmatesoft.sqljet.core.internal.pager.SqlJetPager.open(SqlJetPager.java:395)
        at org.tmatesoft.sqljet.core.internal.btree.SqlJetBtree.open(SqlJetBtree.java:325)
{noformat}

[~tom@atlassian.com]:
{quote}
Because svnkit can also write to svn repositories (although FishEye never uses it to) it tries to open the rep-cache.db file in read/write mode. If it doesn't exist it will usually create it. If it does exist but is read-only it silently falls back to opening it read-only, which is fine as FishEye never invokes any svnkit operations which require a write. In the case of an empty repository whose files are read only the rep-cache.db file doesn't exist and can't be created, which triggers that error. As soon as that file is created (by a commit) svnkit successfully opens the repository.
{quote}
fields.summary: SVNKit error when indexing an empty SVN repo file://

fields.description:
Every 6 months or so we see very hard to diagnose issues around linecounts, including for example:
{code}blame lines not equal to expected linecount{code}

The linecount / blame code really needs a complete re-write, or at least some major refactoring to really understand the problems that we are hitting.

This should include at least:
* much better debugging / logging
* better handling of issues with the repository, eg. when linecounts differ
* fallbacks to SCMs
fields.summary: When indexing some revisions don't get their blame counts calculated properly, causing render-time slowness

fields.description:
The documentation for [/rest-service-fe/search-v1/crossRepositoryQuery|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fisheye.html#d2e180] (which is used by the JIRA-FishEye plugin) needs improvements:
* the parameter {{expand}} which is used to specify the scope of the request is required and undocumented (sample value in practise: "{{expand=changesets\[0:20\].revisions\[0:30\],reviews}}");
* the response' s examples are completely wrong. As an example, this is a typical response received by the plugin:
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<results expand="changesets">
  <changesets>
    <changeset>
      <repositoryName>testrepo1</repositoryName>
      <csid>3db01b0a40e7e6b49e0cd3a59fc0e2ebea469f19</csid>
      <date>2013-05-16T17:24:13+10:00</date>
      <author>Pierre-Etienne Poirot <pepoirot@atlassian.com></author>
      <branch>master</branch>
      <comment>MKY-3: abc (CR-1 review)
</comment>
      <revisions size="1">
        <revision totalLines="2" fileRevisionState="CHANGED" rev="3db01b0a40e7e6b49e0cd3a59fc0e2ebea469f19" path="test" linesRemoved="0" linesAdded="1" date="2013-05-16T17:24:13+10:00" csid="3db01b0a40e7e6b49e0cd3a59fc0e2ebea469f19" contentLink="/browse/~raw,r=3db01b0a40e7e6b49e0cd3a59fc0e2ebea469f19/testrepo1/test" author="Pierre-Etienne Poirot <pepoirot@atlassian.com>" ancestor="5f9a25114754fb33f3971414f7cd6edcdbb8989c">
          <ancestor>5f9a25114754fb33f3971414f7cd6edcdbb8989c</ancestor>
          <comment>MKY-3: abc (CR-1 review)
</comment>
        </revision>
      </revisions>
      <reviews size="1">
        <review>
          <description>{cs:id=3db01b0a40e7e6b49e0cd3a59fc0e2ebea469f19|rep=testrepo1}: MKY-3: abc (CR-1 review)</description>
          <metricsVersion>0</metricsVersion>
          <name>MKY-3: abc (CR-1 review)</name>
          <permaId>
            <id>CR-1</id>
          </permaId>
          <permaIdHistory>CR-1</permaIdHistory>
          <state>Review</state>
        </review>
      </reviews>
    </changeset>
  </changesets>
</results>
{code}
fields.summary: Improvements to the REST doc of /search-v1/crossRepositoryQuery

If I attempt to use a git smart commit with the following line

git commit -m "+review myproj #time 2d #comment my comment"

the comment and time are logged correctly.  But the review is not created.  If I instead use the following.

git commit -m "#comment my comment #time 2d +review myproj "

The #time and the +review show up in the comment, the time is not logged, but the review is properly generated.

fields.description:
A support case was raised (linked in comments) showing that the response times for FishEye 2.7 were _better_ with 30 concurrent requests than with 20 concurrent requests.

Investigation showed that this was applicable to 2.10 and inconsistent - "improved performance" was observed in various (but not all) test runs of 25 to 35 concurrent requests.

We should investigate further with better analysis tools - I was using Apache Benchmark and analysing / graphing requests from the debug logs.

fields.description:
As our Fishible & Stash use increases, the email bombardment from Watch on an indexed repo is increasing. It looks like when someone pushes multiple commits to git/Stash, FishEye will send an email for each commit. Can you combine emails so that a one push = one email? Or allow for a "combine all commits picked up when FishEye checks git, to a single email"? Or - opt in for a daily digest?

One email for one commit sounds reasonable, if it's actionable. But when 8 emails all come in the same second - how does that help keeping them separated?
fields.summary: Combine multiple watch emails from a single push to a single email.

fields.description:
[Documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+avatar+settings] states:
{quote}
External	Use avatars hosted by an external server (e.g. http://www.gravatar.com). Users will also be able to upload their own images to use as avatars via their user profile. See Changing your User Profile. User-defined avatars will override avatars from an external server. 
{quote}
This does not seem to be working as expected. It does not seem possible to upload other profile images from the filesystem, if using an external server.
The documentation needs to be updated accordingly.
Also, there should be no option to upload another avatar, if external server has been selected. This is misleading/confusing.

fields.description:
Sometimes FishEye show this message in an 'Info' box below the Git repository URL:
* run "git gc" manually. See "git help gc" for more information.

This message is a truncated portion of the full message from Git, which says "You may also run "git gc" manually" and is just information from Git. There's no need to run "git gc" manually.

Maybe the message could say this instead:
* "git gc" in progress
